articles.title: Basic Data Analysis in R for Social Sciences
articles.description: "Transdisciplinary Course Program" at the University of Tübingen
articles.contents:
This is the home page for the Basic Data Analysis in R for
Social Sciences course at the University of Tübingen,
“Transdisciplinary
Course Program” (Summer 2022). All course materials will be posted
on this site.
Instructor: Kostiantyn OvsiannikovMeeting times: Thursday,
12:00-13:45 (GMT+1)Venue: online (access via Moodle)Syllabus: click here
Upcoming lectures and assignments: click here

Course title and instructor
Title: Basic Data Analysis in R for Social Sciences
(Summer 2022)
Instructor: Kostiantyn OvsiannikovEmail: ovsiannikov@kochi-tech.ac.jpOffice
Hours: by appointment GitHub: ko-suta 
Purpose and contents of the
class
Focusing on the data analysis in R programming language,
this course will cover the following activities: data exploration,
transformation, visualization, modeling, and communication. It will
concentrate on the relevant socio-economic data-sets, enabling the
participants to complement their prior knowledge and interests with
data-oriented know-how. The students will learn basic statistical
techniques in R through hands-on sessions, getting familiar
with R language through joint exercises. As a result, they
will be able to apply various quantitative skills in their respective
research projects and will be equipped with techniques to master more
advanced R operations in future.
Teaching methods
hands-on sessions;
demonstrations of R capabilities via the customized
website created for this course;
exercises and assignments based on a real data
Qualification objective
Equipping students with basic tools for data analysis in
R that they will be able to apply in their research
projects and beyond.
Requirements
Course attendance of more than 70%
Based on the covered material, completion of several assignments
in R language such as:
Exploratory data analysis
Data modelling
Data visualization

Due to a variety of available R tools suited for these
purposes, students will be encouraged to demonstrate their analytical
and creative skills. Participants will also be able to use datasets of
their own choice and interest, directly applying quantitative techniques
in R for their research projects.
Selected
literature to be used for the class
Wickham, H. & Grolemund, G. (2017). R for Data Science.
Healy, K. (2018). Data
Visualization: A Practical Introduction.
Wilke, C. (2018). Fundamentals of Data
Visualization.
